title: SMALL CAP MOVERS: InfraStrata buoyant after rescuing Titanic shipyard but AIM sinks 1.5%
text:
AIM-listed InfraStrata was floating near the top of the junior market’s leaderboard this week after rescuing the Belfast shipyard where the Titanic was built.

On Tuesday, the group signed a £6million deal for the shipyard’s owner Harland & Wolff, which had fallen into administration in August following the bankruptcy of its former Norwegian owner.

Aside from its historic pedigree, the shipyard has been used more recently to build offshore wind turbines, while its giant Samson and Goliath cranes are considered Belfast landmarks.

InfraStrata signed a £6million deal for the shipyard’s owner Harland & Wolff

InfraStrata, which is currently developing an underground gas storage plant in Islandmagee, just north of Belfast, said the shipyard would be ‘ideally suited’ for its projects, while chief executive John Wood said the firm would not only save the jobs of Harland and Wolff’s 79 remaining staff but also expand the workforce to around 400.

The news put wind into the company’s sails, with the stock rising 13 per cent over the week at 0.53p.

The AIM All-Share was less buoyant, sinking 1.5 per cent to 859.8 this week, though fared better than the FTSE 100, which plunged 4.4 per cent to 7,100.

Also on the decline was Volga Gas, which was left deflated after a lower production for September sent its shares down 22 per cent to 29p.

The firm reported that it had produced 10.5 million cubic feet per day during the month, 13 per cent lower than in August, which was blamed on reduced output from its Vostochno-Makarovskoye gas field in Russia.

Issues at the Barryroe project off the coast of Ireland caused a headache for Lansdowne Oil & Gas, which slipped 8 per cent to 0.9p after refusing to keep waiting for a $9million loan from China's APEC.

Lansdowne’s partner at Barryroe, Providence Resources, also tumbled 23 per cent to 4p on the news.

A pit wall collapse at its New Liberty Gold mine in Liberia sent shares in Avesoro Resources down 2 per cent to 92p, however, the company confirmed that there had been no injuries or equipment damage.

Digital marketing group Mporium lost over half its value, crashing 54 per cent to 0.4p, as plans to buy agency Click Labs, the funds for which would be raised through a share placing, were not well received by investors.

Zinc Media also found itself in shareholder’s bad books after wider losses in its latest full-year sent the stock down 17 per cent to 0.3p.

Among the risers, antibiotic developer Summit Therapeutics stood out for its healthy rise of 30 per cent to 28p after saying its next-generation antibiotic ‘significantly improved’ the quality of life of people with c.difficile, an infection that causes diarrhoea.

Marketing firm Jaywing gained altitude after a cash boost from two of its major shareholders sent the shares soaring 69 per cent to 6p.

Jaywing’s backers had purchased its £5.2million loan facility from Barclays and had immediately increased it to £8.2million, allowing the company to pay off its overdrafts and realign the business.

Events organiser Aeorema Communications climbed 12 per cent to 30p as it implied that it could see higher margins next year, while also reporting a rise in profits for its latest full year to £375,010 from £58,685.

Mobile data provider Crimson Tide hit a high water mark after a contract win sent its shares up 11 per cent to 2.6p.

The deal with an unnamed UK retailer will bring in a minimum of £1.4million in revenue over three years and will involve Crimson Tide’s mpro5 platform being used in 4,000 retail locations across the UK and Ireland.

Junior explorer Power Metals also marched 17 per cent higher to 0.5p after confirming the existence of nickel sulphide targets at its Molopo Farms project in Botswana.

Meanwhile, Bahamas Petroleum gushed 10 per cent higher to 2p as confirmation that it was not pursuing plans for an imminent fundraising brought a sigh of relief from investors.
